questions.text: During which developmental week does the heartbeat initiate in the cardiac region?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - 4

Developmental Stage

Heartbeat

3rd week of gestation (21-22 days)

Begins as a simple tubular structure and initiates spontaneous contractions

4th week of gestation

Heart tube undergoes looping, and the heart starts beating rhythmically

5th week of gestation

Heart chambers begin to form, and the heart rate increases

8th week of gestation

Four-chambered heart is well-formed, and heartbeat can be detected using ultrasound

9th-10th week of gestation

Heartbeat becomes more regular and coordinated

End of 12th week of gestation

Fetal heart rate can be heard using a Doppler device

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options is unable to pass through the placenta? A. Iron B. Albumin C. Immunoglobulin M D. Immunoglobulin G
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C: B and C

Substance

Explanation

Oxygen

Oxygen is essential for fetal respiration and can easily diffuse across the placenta from the maternal bloodstream.

Nutrients (Glucose, Amino Acids)

Important nutrients, including glucose and amino acids, are transported across the placenta to provide nourishment for the developing fetus.

Immunoglobulin G (IgG)

IgG antibodies, produced by the mother in response to infections or vaccinations, can cross the placenta and provide passive immunity to the fetus.

Hormones (Thyroid Hormones, Estrogen, Progesterone)

Certain hormones produced by the mother, such as thyroid hormones, estrogen, and progesterone, can cross the placenta and impact fetal development.

Carbon Dioxide (CO2)

Carbon dioxide, a waste product produced by the fetus, can diffuse across the placenta and be eliminated through the maternal bloodstream.

Medications and Drugs

Various medications and drugs, both therapeutic and recreational, have the potential to cross the placenta and affect the fetus. It is important to consider the safety of medications during pregnancy.

References:

  • ↳ Technique choice depends on bowel condition, location, surgeon preference, and patient factors.
  • ↳ Single-Layer, Extramucosal Suture: Outer bowel layers are sutured, excluding the inner mucosal layer. Reduces leakage risk, especially in necrotic bowel cases.
  • ↳ Double-Layer Technique: Both seromuscular and mucosal layers are sutured separately, offering added reinforcement and widely used in anastomosis.

questions.text: ​​​​​​​In the OPD, a 35-year-old male presented with concerns of passing dark-colored stools . Following an endoscopy, the patient was diagnosed with an upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleed. Which anatomical structure serves as a distinguishing point to differentiate it from a lower GI bleed?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Ligament of Treitz:

References:

  • ↳ The Ligament of Treitz, also known as the suspensory muscle of the duodenum, is a fibrous band located at the junction between the duodenum (the first part of the small intestine) and the jejunum (the second part of the small intestine).
  • ↳ This anatomical landmark serves as a useful reference point for distinguishing between upper and lower GI bleeding.
  • ↳ Incorrect Options:
  • ↳ Incorrect Options:
  • ↳ Option A - Ampulla of Vater: The Ampulla of Vater is the site where the common bile duct and the pancreatic duct join and enter the duodenum.
  • ↳ Option A - Ampulla of Vater:
  • ↳ Option C - Superior duodenal flexure: The superior duodenal flexure refers to the curved segment of the duodenum, where it transitions from the descending part to the horizontal part.
  • ↳ Option C - Superior duodenal flexure:
  • ↳ Option D - Ileocecal junction: The ileocecal junction is the point where the small intestine (ileum) connects to the large intestine (cecum).
  • ↳ Option D - Ileocecal junction:
    • References:

    • ↳ It is a fibrous band connecting the fourth part of the duodenum to the diaphragm, situated at the level of the duodenojejunal flexure.
    • ↳ Used to differentiate between the upper and lower gastrointestinal tract, marking the transition between the proximal (upper) small intestine (duodenum) and the distal (lower) small intestine (jejunum).
    • ↳ Important in diagnosing and classifying gastrointestinal bleeding. It helps differentiate upper GI bleeding (above the Ligament of Treitz) from lower GI bleeding (below it).
    • ↳ A crucial landmark in various gastrointestinal surgeries, including gastric bypass and small intestine resection. Surgeons use it as a reference point to identify the duodenojejunal junction and plan interventions accordingly.

questions.explanation:
Correct Option C: A

Aspect Description
Common Name Dog hookworm (also known as the Brazilian dog hookworm)
Scientific Name Ancylostoma braziliense
Phylum Nematoda (roundworms)
Habitat Small intestine of dogs and other canids
Geographic Distribution Found in tropical and subtropical regions, particularly in the Americas
Lifecycle - Direct life cycle, involving the passage of eggs in the feces of infected animals. - Larvae hatch from eggs and develop into infective larvae in the environment. - Infection occurs through skin penetration by infective larvae or ingestion of larvae-contaminated material.- Adults in the small intestine produce eggs, restarting the cycle.
Morphology (Adult) - Small, slender nematode. - Males: 8-11 mm in length with a curved posterior end. - Females: 10-13 mm in length with a straighter posterior end.
Morphology (Eggs) - Small, oval-shaped eggs with thin shells. - Eggs are passed in the feces of infected animals.
Clinical Significance - Ancylostoma braziliense can cause a condition known as cutaneous larva migrans (CLM) in humans, characterized by itchy, serpiginous skin lesions. - In dogs, the infection can lead to gastrointestinal signs such as diarrhea and anemia.
Zoonotic Potential - Ancylostoma braziliense is zoonotic, and humans can become accidental hosts, experiencing cutaneous larva migrans (creeping eruption) when larvae penetrate the skin.
Prevention and Control - Regular deworming of dogs to reduce the shedding of infective larvae. - Proper disposal of dog feces to minimize environmental contamination.
Diagnosis - Identification of characteristic eggs in fecal samples through microscopic examination. - Clinical signs and history of exposure to contaminated environments.
Treatment - Anthelmintic medications, such as benzimidazoles or macrocyclic lactones, are effective in treating Ancylostoma braziliense infections in dogs. - Cutaneous larva migrans in humans may be self-limiting, but medications may be prescribed for symptomatic relief.

Pathophysiology

Inflammation and irritation of the tendons and their surrounding sheath

Common Causes

Repetitive hand and wrist motions, overuse injuries

Capillary refill time > 2 seconds = vascular compromise

Pulse examination Absent/diminished distal pulses = arterial injury
Skin status Open wounds = open fracture → risk of infection
Pain disproportionate to injury Suspect compartment syndrome
Neurological status Paresthesia, motor weakness = possible nerve injury
Swelling or tense compartments Consider fasciotomy if compartment pressure is high

Open fractures Bone exposed or wound >1 cm over fracture site Emergency ortho consult
Vascular compromise Absent pulses, CRT >2 sec, cold limb Emergency ortho + vascular
Compartment syndrome Pain out of proportion, paresthesia, pallor, pulselessness, paralysis Fasciotomy indicated
Joint dislocations Shoulder, knee, hip dislocations Urgent (but not always emergency)
Spinal trauma Neurological deficits, high-impact injury Immobilize + MRI/CT

questions.text: Identify the given fracture?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A: Colles Fractu

Definition Colles Fracture is a type of distal radius fracture characterized by a break at the distal end of the radius bone in the forearm. It often involves dorsal displacement and angulation of the distal fragment. Named after the Irish surgeon Abraham Colles.
Epidemiology - Most common type of wrist fracture in adults, particularly in the elderly population. - Often associated with falls onto an outstretched hand.
Mechanism of Injury - Typically occurs due to a fall on an outstretched hand with the wrist extended. - Axial loading on the radius leads to the characteristic fracture pattern.
Clinical Presentation - Deformity: Dorsal displacement and "dinner fork" or "bayonet" deformity may be visible. - Pain: Localized pain at the site of the fracture. - Swelling: Immediate swelling around the wrist.
Radiographic Features - Dorsal Tilt: On X-rays, dorsal displacement and dorsal tilt of the distal fragment are characteristic. - Radial Shortening: Shortening of the radius may also be observed.
Classification - Extra-articular (Type I): Fracture occurs just above the wrist joint. - Partial Articular (Type II): Fracture extends into the joint but does not involve the joint surface. - Complete Articular (Type III): Fracture extends into the joint and involves the joint surface.
Treatment - Closed Reduction and Casting: Common initial approach, especially for less displaced fractures. - Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF): Considered for more complex or displaced fractures, or cases where closed reduction is not successful.
Complications - Malunion: Improper alignment during healing may lead to deformity. - Nerve or Vascular Injury: Rare but possible, especially in more severe fractures.

options.text: Pain in both movement and at rest

questions.explanation:

Diagnosis

Description

Osteoarthritis

Degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage and subsequent joint pain and stiffness

Rheumatoid arthritis

Autoimmune disease causing chronic inflammation of the joints, leading to pain, swelling, and joint deformity

Gout

Inflammatory arthritis caused by the buildup of uric acid crystals in the joints, resulting in sudden and severe pain

Fibromyalgia

Chronic condition characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tenderness at specific trigger points

Bursitis

Inflammation of the bursae, fluid-filled sacs that cushion and reduce friction between bones, tendons, and muscles

Tendinitis

Inflammation of a tendon, often caused by overuse or repetitive motion, resulting in localized pain and tenderness

Muscular strain or sprain

Injury to muscles or ligaments due to overstretching or tearing, leading to pain, swelling, and limited range of motion

Stress fractures

Small cracks or breaks in bones, usually caused by repetitive stress or overuse, resulting in localized pain and swelling

Herniated disc

Condition where the soft inner material of a spinal disc leaks through the outer layer, causing nerve compression and pain

Sciatica

Pain radiating along the path of the sciatic nerve, often caused by compression or irritation of the nerve

questions.text: Which of the following is not employed in evaluating body fat?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D: B

Assessment Method

BODY FAT ASSESSMENT

Body Mass Index (BMI)

Calculated by dividing an individual's weight (in kilograms) by the square of their height (in meters).

Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DXA)

A precise method that measures body composition, including bone mineral density, lean mass, and fat mass, using low-dose X-rays.

Skinfold Thickness Measurement

Measures the thickness of subcutaneous fat at specific sites on the body using calipers.

Bioelectrical Impedance Analysis (BIA)

Uses electrical impedance to estimate body composition. A low-level electrical current is passed through the body, measuring resistance.

Air Displacement Plethysmography (ADP)

Involves measuring body volume and density by sitting inside a small chamber that uses air displacement.

Hydrostatic Weighing

Determines body density by measuring a person's weight while submerged underwater.

Near-Infrared Interactance

Measures the reflection and absorption of near-infrared light to estimate body fat content.

Waist Circumference

Measures the circumference of the waist, providing an indirect indicator of abdominal fat and health risks.

questions.text: In a population of 1000 individuals, a screening test was conducted for DM (diabetes mellitus). It showed that 90 individuals tested positive for DM. Subsequently, a gold standard test for DM was conducted, and it showed that 100 individuals tested positive. Your task is to determine the sensitivity of the screening test.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - 9

References:

  • ↳ Sensitivity of a screening test is a measure that indicates the proportion of true positive results correctly identified by the test. It quantifies the test's ability to correctly detect individuals who have the condition or disease being screened for.
  • ↳ The sensitivity is calculated using the following formula:
  • ↳ Sensitivity = True Positives / (True Positives + False Negatives)
  • ↳ True positives refer to the number of individuals who have the condition or disease and are correctly identified as positive by the screening test. False negatives refer to the number of individuals who have the condition or disease but are incorrectly identified as negative by the screening test.
  • ↳ To calculate the sensitivity, you need the values of true positives and false negatives. These values can be obtained by comparing the results of the screening test to a reference standard or gold standard test.
  • ↳ For example, if out of 100 individuals who truly have the disease, the screening test correctly identifies 80 as positive (true positives) and misses 20 (false negatives), the sensitivity would be:
  • ↳ Sensitivity = 80 / (80 + 20) = 80 / 100 = 0.8 or 80%
  • ↳ So, in this case, the sensitivity of the screening test would be 80%.

  • Direct contact

Droplet infection
  • Droplet nuclei

  • E.g. Tetanus
  • Vector borne

  • E.g. Dog bite, HIV by needle prick injury

Live Vaccines

Killed Vaccines

Nature of the Vaccine

Contains a weakened or attenuated form of the infectious agent

Contains inactivated or killed versions of the infectious agent

Immune Response

Stimulates a strong immune response, including both humoral and cellular immunity

Stimulates a relatively weaker immune response primarily involving humoral immunity

Duration of Protection

Usually provides long-lasting immunity

May require booster doses to maintain immunity

Vaccine Shedding

May shed the weakened form of the infectious agent, potentially causing mild illness in rare cases

Does not shed the infectious agent

Vaccine Efficacy

Generally higher efficacy due to the replication of the weakened agent in the body

Efficacy may be lower due to the absence of replication and reduced immune response

Risk of Reversion

Small risk of reversion to a more virulent form of the infectious agent

No risk of reversion to a more virulent form

Examples

Measles, mumps, rubella, varicella (chickenpox), oral polio vaccine, yellow fever, rotavirus

Influenza (injectable), polio (inactivated), hepatitis A, pertussis (acellular), pneumococcal conjugate vaccine

Identify the structure marked in the CT scan shown below:
Which of the following conditions can be treated with pirenzepine?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Peptic ulcer

Drug Class

Examples

Mechanism of Action

Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs)

Omeprazole, Esomeprazole, Lansoprazole

Inhibit the proton pump (H+/K+ ATPase) in gastric parietal cells, reducing acid secretion and promoting ulcer healing.

Histamine H2 Receptor Antagonists

Ranitidine, Famotidine, Cimetidine

Block the histamine H2 receptors on gastric parietal cells, reducing acid secretion and promoting ulcer healing.

Antacids

Aluminum hydroxide, Magnesium hydroxide

Neutralize gastric acid, providing temporary relief from symptoms and promoting ulcer healing.

Mucosal Protective Agents

Sucralfate, Misoprostol

Enhance mucosal defense mechanisms, promote mucosal healing, and reduce acid secretion.

Antibiotics

Amoxicillin, Clarithromycin, Metronidazole

Used in combination therapy to eradicate Helicobacter pylori infection, which is associated with peptic ulcers.

M1 Blockers

Pirenzepine, Telenzepine

Selectively block muscarinic M1 receptors in the gastric parietal cells, reducing acid secretion and promoting ulcer healing.

Common Iliac Arteries L4 Aortic bifurcation Internal and external iliac arteries Pelvis, lower limbs

questions.text: Leiden mutation is of factor:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A: V

Condition

Description

Factor V Leiden mutation

Genetic mutation in factor V that increases risk of abnormal blood clotting

Prothrombin gene mutation

Genetic mutation in the prothrombin gene leading to increased clotting activity

Antithrombin deficiency

Deficiency in antithrombin, a protein that inhibits blood clotting

Protein C deficiency

Deficiency in protein C, a natural anticoagulant

Protein S deficiency

Deficiency in protein S, which acts as a cofactor for protein C

Elevated factor VIII levels

Increased levels of factor VIII, a clotting protein

Condition

Description

Pregnancy

Increased risk of blood clot formation during pregnancy

Oral contraceptive use

Use of hormonal contraceptives can increase the risk of blood clots

Estrogen therapy

Administration of estrogen-containing medications

Obesity

Obesity is associated with an increased risk of blood clots

Immobility

Prolonged periods of immobility can lead to blood clot formation

Surgery

Surgical procedures can trigger a hypercoagulable state

Cancer

Certain cancers and cancer treatments increase the risk of blood clots

Antiphospholipid syndrome

Autoimmune disorder that causes abnormal clotting

Nephrotic syndrome

Kidney disorder characterized by protein loss in urine

questions.text: What is the most effective stimulus for increasing aldosterone secretion ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Hyperk

Conditions that alter aldosterone secretion

A. Conditions that increase secretion
  1. Hemorrhage
  2. Hypovolemia
  3. Hyperkalemia
  4. Hyponatremia
  5. Standing
  6. Anxiety
  7. Physical trauma and surgery
  8. Secondary hyperaldosteronism: Aldosterone secretion may increase in congestive heart failure, cirrhosis of liver, and nephritic syndrome.

B. Conditions that decrease secretion
  1. Expansion of ECF volume
  2. Hypernatremia
  3. Hypokalemia
